abstract:
In Thursday’s New York Times, Steve Lohr reports on Yahoo’s pick for its next chief executive — Scott Thompson, the president of PayPal, the online payment service owned by eBay.

Mr. Thompson has a big job ahead of him. Yahoo, one of the first Internet sensations, has been struggling. Unlike other giants on the Web, it has failed to embrace social media and mobile devices. And it has been losing ground over all in the critical battle for online ads. Last year Facebook overtook Yahoo in online display advertising, according to eMarketer, a research firm. Yet Yahoo has one of the largest audiences on the Web, and will report net profit of more than $1 billion in 2011 on revenue of nearly $4.44 billion, estimates Jordan Rohan, an analyst at Stifel Nicolaus.

Mr. Thompson, whose expertise is in technology rather than digital media or corporate turnarounds, replaces Carol A. Bartz, who was dismissed in September after a rocky two-year effort trying to turn the company around. She left with some flamboyance, announcing in a blunt e-mail blast to Yahoo’s 13,400 employees that she had been fired.

The appointment of Mr. Thompson was widely covered. Kit Eaton at Fast Company and Robert Hof at Forbes both offered five suggestions for how the new chief executive can fix the company. Among the tips on both lists: pick a focus and don’t try to be all things to all people.
